Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant supports the completion and launch of the ANDESITE CubeSat constellation mission consisting of 9 spacecraft. These CubeSat will make spatially-resolved measurements of electric currents in the ionosphere, which are a critical pathway of energy flow from the magnetosphere into the ionosphere. The research effort will demonstrate that critical scientific measurements can made using CubeSat constellations for use in space weather monitoring. The grant will support a junior scientist in the community and provide education and training for graduate and undergraduate students.

The ANDESITE CubeSats will fly through the auroral zones with small inter-spacecraft separations (<10km) to study the small-scale spatial structure of Magnetosphere- Ionosphere coupling. The ANDESITE mission is manifested on the Rocket Labs Electron rocket for a launch into a near polar orbit. Once in space, the 6U bus will deploy 8 pico-satellites to fly in a constellation communicating over a mesh network. Each element in the constellation will make a 3-axis magnetic field measurement which will be used to identify the local current density. The mission serves as a pathfinder to demonstrate the use of small spacecraft constellations with small separations for use in space weather monitoring. This research will test, launch, and operate the spacecraft constellation on orbit, and perform data analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ANDESITE cubesat has been developed to study the transfer of energy from the sun to the Earth’s space environment. This will be done through monitoring the electrical currents associated with the aurora or northern lights. The cubesat or cube-satellite has been developed and will be operated by students at Boston University when launched through NASA’s CubeSat Launch Initiative (CSLI).

To accomplish its science objective, the ANDESITE cubesat (the mule) will deploy 8 picosatellites (nodes) and form a 9-spacecraft constellation with separations less than 10 km. Operationally the constellation will form a mesh network where the nodes pass data to the mule for transport to the ground. Each node will measure the local magnetic field which can be perturbed by a local electric current. This project represents the first inflight deployment of such a mesh communication network. Scientifically, the mission will make ground-breaking measurements in magnetosphere-ionosphere coupling through multipoint magnetic field measurements of the variable magnetic field in the auroral current regions.

The project also provided large educational outputs. Through the mission development, 26 undergraduate and graduate students gained hands-on experience developing and testing flight hardware. These students spanned departments at Boston University including Physics, Astronomy, Mechanical Engineering, Electrical Engineering, as well Biomedical Engineering. The students functioned as a team passing through life-cycles reviews as well as development and performance testing for the space mission. The project has also engaged students and motivated them to continue in STEM fields. All students that have graduated from the project have continued in STEM either through graduate school or employment and many have continued on in aerospace engineering.
